titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gianni Bertini Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:21

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

langmaterial.language: In Italian, French, English, and German.

did.abstract: The collection consists of scrapbooks, correspondence, photographs, posters, visual poetry, artwork, writings, audiovisual materials, and electronic media documenting the life and work of Gianni Bertini. Correspondence includes letters from artists, galleries, and others. Notable correspondents include P. A. Benoit, Jean-François Bory, Henri Chopin, Jacqueline de Jong, Jean Dubuffet, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Sarenco, and Serge Vandercam. Artwork includes examples of MEC-Art (mechanical artwork), paintings, and other works by Bertini, P. A. Benoit, Henri Chopin, Bernard Heidsieck, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Ben Vautier, and others.

userestrict.head: Ownership & Copyright
userestrict.p: The Gianni Bertini Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Gianni Bertini Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four groupings: July 2012 Acquisition; August 2012 Acquisition; September 2013 Acquisitions; and January 2016 Acquisition.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.
Box 110 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 117 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: July 2012 Acquisition: Purchased from John Benjamins Antiquariat b.v. and Phillipe Luiggi on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2012.
August 2012 Acquisition: Purchased from Derbylius Libreria Galleria di Carla Roncato on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2012.
September 2013 Acquisitions: Purchased from John Benjamins Antiquariat b.v. and Phillipe Luiggi on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund.
January 2016 Acquisition: Purchased from Philippe Luigi on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below and titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Gianni Bertini
bioghist.p: Gianni Bertini (1922-2010) was an Italian artist and visual poet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of scrapbooks, correspondence, photographs, posters, visual poetry, artwork, writings, audiovisual materials, and electronic media documenting the life and work of Gianni Bertini. Correspondence includes letters from artists, galleries, and others. Notable correspondents include P. A. Benoit, Jean-François Bory, Henri Chopin, Jacqueline de Jong, Jean Dubuffet, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Sarenco, and Serge Vandercam. Artwork includes examples of MEC-Art (mechanical artwork), paintings, and other works by Bertini, P. A. Benoit, Henri Chopin, Bernard Heidsieck, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Ben Vautier, and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from John Benjamins Antiquariat b.v. and Phillipe Luiggi on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: Scrapbooks, 1946-2007; Correspondence, 1947-2010; Photographs, undated; Posters, 1954-1980; MEC-Art, 1970s-2000s; Visual poetry, 1961-1965; Artwork, 1951-2006; Electronic media, undated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The bulk of the correspondence is organized chronologically. Some correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name, and correspondence with publisher P. A. Benoit (PAB) was not integrated into the primary chronological sequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes letters from artists, galleries, and others. Transcribed correspondence includes both originals and transcriptions. Notable correspondents include P. A. Benoit (PAB), Jean-François Bory, Henri Chopin, Jacqueline de Jong, Jean Dubuffet, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Sarenco, and Serge Vandercam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of examples of Bertini's MEC-Art, or mechanical art.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Titles for artwork in this series include item numbers from "Hommage à Gianni Bertini (1922-2010), Joint catalog no 22 (items 1-173), Addenda (items 174-183)" issued by John Benjamins Antiquariat b.v. and Philippe Luiggi. Catalog numbers not present were either not acquired by the Beinecke Library or were cataloged separately as published material. Items identified as "part of" a catalog number have had printed material separated to be cataloged as published material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artwork includes paintings and other works by Bertini, P. a. Benoit, Henri Chopin, Bernard Heidsieck, Jean-Clarence Lambert, Ben Vautier, and others.
